issue.title: When test writes something to the stdErr there is no guaranteed way to link a test-output event to a target test using ITestEventListener

repository.name: nunit-console
repository.description: NUnit Console runner and test engine

issue.body:
For example:

- Unit test `SuccessfulStdErrorTest` has code: `System.Console.Error.WriteLine("errorout");`

- ITestEventListener receives the following events:
```
<start-test id="0-1001" parentId="0-1000" name="SuccessfulStdErrorTest" fullname="Foo.Tests.UnitTests1.SuccessfulStdErrorTest" type="TestMethod" />

<test-output stream="Error" testname="Foo.Tests.UnitTests1.SuccessfulStdErrorTest"><![CDATA[errorout
]]></test-output>
```

`test-output` has no information id/parentId about a target test and there is no way to attach this error output. It is important to note that these events could be received from different tests simultaneously.

See this [sample](https://github.com/nunit/nunit-console/files/1418559/sample.zip)

body:
As far as I can see, @NikolayPianikov is correct - there's currently no reliable way to associate test output with a particular test, when running in parallel, and test-names are not guaranteed to be unique.

This sounds a sensible feature for any GUI runners which wish to associate output with a particular test.

I suggest adding a `testId` field. @NikolayPianikov - is there any reason I'm missing to also have parentId in the test-output node?
I agree with testId. It's parentId that I have a problem with. NUnit's ids are unique within the run.
I would like to work on this issue. But I need more explanation

Find where we create `<test-output...>` elements in `TestOutput.ToXml()`. Add an `id` attribute along with the existing `stream` and `testname` attributes. Although order is not significant, you should probably use the same order as we use for test cases in our result XML to avoid confusion.

Thanks @ChrisMaddock. It is been a while a did not pull from master but when I did to day and I tried to build the solution, I got a bunch of errors related to assembly missing. One of the errors: **"System.Linq.Expressions 4.1.1 provides a compile-time reference assembly for System.Linq.Expressions on .NETCoreApp,Version=v1.0, but there is no run-time assembly compatible with win7."**
 
I tried restore Nuget packages many times but it did not help.

Do I need a specific configuration?
Note: I'm using Visual Studio 2017 on Windows 10 machine

You may need to build in the command line, the first time around. After the initial package restore is done, I think working straight in VS will work. We‚Äôre working on fixing this.

Open a command prompt in your directory, and run ‚Äòbuild‚Äô.

I tried to use cmd and I get new error: 
**CommandLineTests.cs(137,90): error CS1061: 'IEnumerable<string>' does not contain a definition for 'ToArray' an
d no extension method 'ToArray' accepting a first argument of type 'IEnumerable<string>' could be found (are yo
u missing a using directive or an assembly reference?) [C:\...\nunit\src\NUnitFramework
\nunitlite.tests\nunitlite.tests-netstandard13.csproj]
An error occurred when executing task 'BuildNetStandard13'.**

Is there a document that could help to do proper build or set up a dev environment?
BUILDING.md in the root of the project.
